articles.headline: Mueller Has Early Draft of Trump Letter Giving Reasons for Firing Comey
articles.snippet: The special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, has a copy of a letter President Trump wanted to send to James B. Comey explaining the rationale for firing him. The White House counsel blocked the president from sending it.
articles.abstract: The special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, has a copy of a letter President Trump wanted to send to James B. Comey explaining the rationale for firing him. The White House counsel blocked the president from sending it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, has obtained a letter drafted by President Trump and a top political aide that offered an unvarnished view of Mr. Trump’s thinking in the days before the president fired the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Forceful Chief of Staff Grates on Trump, and the Feeling Is Mutual
articles.snippet: John Kelly is fully aware of the president’s resentment about being managed, and his appeal has gradually dimmed. But Mr. Trump needs Mr. Kelly more than Mr. Kelly needs him.
articles.abstract: John Kelly is fully aware of the president’s resentment about being managed, and his appeal has gradually dimmed. But Mr. Trump needs Mr. Kelly more than Mr. Kelly needs him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump was in an especially ornery mood after staff members gently suggested he refrain from injecting politics into day-to-day issues of governing after last month’s raucous rally in Arizona, and he responded by lashing out at the most senior aide in his presence.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: In Beaumont, Tex., Hopscotching for Food, Water and Shelter
articles.snippet: For many residents of southeast Texas, the last few days have been spent on a series of roads to nowhere.
articles.abstract: For many residents of southeast Texas, the last few days have been spent on a series of roads to nowhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEAUMONT, Tex. — Carrie Chambliss climbed into her husband’s truck on Friday and drove a winding route some 70 miles, plowing through deep water, to get from her home in Mauriceville to a grocery store in Beaumont that had “barely anything” left.
articles.byline: By Rick Rojas and Campbell Robertson

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Courts Brand-Name Teachers, Raising Ethics Issues
articles.snippet: As teachers launch personal brands and cast themselves as influencers, start-ups and tech giants alike are racing to cultivate them to spread their wares.
articles.abstract: As teachers launch personal brands and cast themselves as influencers, start-ups and tech giants alike are racing to cultivate them to spread their wares.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAPLETON, N.D. — One of the tech-savviest teachers in the United States teaches third grade here at Mapleton Elementary, a public school with about 100 students in the sparsely populated plains west of Fargo.

articles.headline: For One Family in Houston, an Overwhelming Start to Recovery
articles.snippet: With no preparation and few road maps to guide them, hurricane survivors like the Amofas are stumbling through their first bewildering days after Harvey.
articles.abstract: With no preparation and few road maps to guide them, hurricane survivors like the Amofas are stumbling through their first bewildering days after Harvey.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — She couldn’t sleep. Not now.

articles.headline: Desperate Rohingya Flee Myanmar on Trail of Suffering: ‘It Is All Gone’
articles.snippet: Tens of thousands escaped into Bangladesh, where they told New York Times journalists accounts of massacres by security forces. Hunger and hardship await them across the border.
articles.abstract: Tens of thousands escaped into Bangladesh, where they told New York Times journalists accounts of massacres by security forces. Hunger and hardship await them across the border.
articles.lead_paragraph: REZU AMTALI, Bangladesh — They stumble down muddy ravines and flooded creeks through miles of hills and jungle in Bangladesh, and thousands more come each day, in a line stretching to the monsoon-darkened horizon.

articles.headline: As Bike-Sharing Brings Out Bad Manners, China Asks, What’s Wrong With Us?
articles.snippet: The popularity of shared-use bikes has brought a wave of misbehavior, raising questions about social decay and the decline of decorum.
articles.abstract: The popularity of shared-use bikes has brought a wave of misbehavior, raising questions about social decay and the decline of decorum.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Liu Lijing, a mechanic in Beijing, does not usually pay much attention to manners. He does not mind when people blast loud music, and he strolls the alleyways near his home in a tank top stained with grease. But when a stranger recently ditched a bicycle in the bushes outside his door, Mr. Liu was irate.

articles.headline: Long List of Top Democrats Have 2020, and Money, on Their Minds
articles.snippet: Well before most of them will announce they are running, prospective Democratic candidates for president are taking steps to lay the financial foundation for a campaign.
articles.abstract: Well before most of them will announce they are running, prospective Democratic candidates for president are taking steps to lay the financial foundation for a campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Aides to Senator Kamala Harris of California say that her fund-raisers in Martha’s Vineyard and the Hamptons this summer have been all about helping Democrats in 2018. Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s allies say his new political group is building an email list so he can communicate directly with his supporters about the future of the party and the country. And Representative Tim Ryan of Ohio says he has been traveling to Iowa and New Hampshire in part because “I like being out around the country.”
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Rachel Shorey

articles.headline: North Korean Nuclear Test Draws U.S. Warning of ‘Massive Military Response’
articles.snippet: The North’s sixth nuclear test, on Sunday, was its most powerful yet, but it was unclear whether it had in fact detonated a hydrogen bomb.
articles.abstract: The North’s sixth nuclear test, on Sunday, was its most powerful yet, but it was unclear whether it had in fact detonated a hydrogen bomb.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — North Korea’s detonation of a sixth nuclear bomb on Sunday prompted the Trump administration to warn that even the threat to use such a weapon against the United States and its allies “will be met with a massive military response.’’
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: Now on Stage: The Countdown to a New Taylor Swift Album
articles.snippet: The release of a new Taylor Swift album is always an instructive lesson in marketing. But with streaming dominant, the playbook is being rewritten.
articles.abstract: The release of a new Taylor Swift album is always an instructive lesson in marketing. But with streaming dominant, the playbook is being rewritten.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the music industry, the rollout of a new Taylor Swift album is always a master class in marketing, and the release of “Look What You Made Me Do,” the first single, is a case in point.

articles.headline: ‘Brexit’ Threatens Subsidies for U.K.’s Landed Gentry, and Queen
articles.snippet: Millions in European Union farm subsidies that go to Britain’s rich and famous — including Queen Elizabeth II — could be excised after the country leaves the bloc.
articles.abstract: Millions in European Union farm subsidies that go to Britain’s rich and famous — including Queen Elizabeth II — could be excised after the country leaves the bloc.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANDRINGHAM, England — It is a club that includes some of the world’s richest people. There are dukes, sheikhs, flamboyant entrepreneurs — even Queen Elizabeth II and other members of the royal family.

articles.headline: Trump Shifts Labor Policy Focus From Worker to Entrepreneur
articles.snippet: The administration’s approach fits with the president’s often-stated view of what drives economic success.
articles.abstract: The administration’s approach fits with the president’s often-stated view of what drives economic success.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even by the standards of the Trump era, one of the more unusual departures from recent Washington practice came in June, in a case before the Supreme Court involving worker rights.

articles.headline: Guinot, the French Cosmetics Company, Bets on Tennis Underdogs
articles.snippet: In order to maximize exposure at major tournaments, Guinot makes short-term endorsement deals with players scheduled to face the sport’s biggest stars.
articles.abstract: In order to maximize exposure at major tournaments, Guinot makes short-term endorsement deals with players scheduled to face the sport’s biggest stars.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sweden’s Robin Soderling, who was ranked 25th in 2009, stuns No. 1 Rafael Nadal at that year’s French Open, where he had been undefeated. At the same tournament three years later, the 111th-ranked Virginie Razzano of France beats Serena Williams in the first round. At this year’s Australian Open, the 117th-ranked Denis Istomin of Uzbekistan defeats Novak Djokovic.

articles.headline: Over 21 Miles of Highway, Snapshots of a Resilient Houston
articles.snippet: The stretch of I-45 that leads downtown from near George Bush Intercontinental Airport captures some of the essence of what has often been a misunderstood city.
articles.abstract: The stretch of I-45 that leads downtown from near George Bush Intercontinental Airport captures some of the essence of what has often been a misunderstood city.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — This city sprawls over 600 square miles, an area so big that Chicago, Philadelphia, Baltimore and Detroit could all fit within it simultaneously. The nine-county Houston metropolitan region, covering more than 10,000 square miles, is almost as large as the entire state of Massachusetts.

articles.headline: Eager to Create Blue-Collar Jobs, a Small Business Struggles
articles.snippet: A Michigan auto parts company has transformed itself and made money. But its chief finds herself caught between demands to lower costs and lift wages.
articles.abstract: A Michigan auto parts company has transformed itself and made money. But its chief finds herself caught between demands to lower costs and lift wages.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Mich. — Anita-Maria Quillen blended a strawberry-banana shake, tucked high heels into a Louis Vuitton bag and fired off last-minute requests at her little boys and their sitter.

articles.headline: Motives of North Korea’s Leader Baffle Americans and Allies
articles.snippet: With the country again conducting a nuclear test, no issue confounds analysts more than what Kim Jong-un, its dictator, really wants.
articles.abstract: With the country again conducting a nuclear test, no issue confounds analysts more than what Kim Jong-un, its dictator, really wants.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — What does Kim Jong-un want?
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Trump Seriously Considering Ending DACA, With 6-Month Delay
articles.snippet: The plan, which officials said could still be changed, would give Congress time to come up with a legislative solution.
articles.abstract: The plan, which officials said could still be changed, would give Congress time to come up with a legislative solution.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Read more on the Supreme Court’s decision on President Trump and DACA.]
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: U.S. Urges Fuel Cutoff for North Korea, Saying It’s ‘Begging for War’
articles.snippet: Trump administration officials said a cutoff was a last best chance to resolve the standoff with the North using sanctions rather than military means.
articles.abstract: Trump administration officials said a cutoff was a last best chance to resolve the standoff with the North using sanctions rather than military means.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump Administration, warning that North Korea is “begging for war,” is pressing China and other members of the United Nations Security Council to cut off all oil and other fuels to the country.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Choe Sang-Hun
